Answer:

Main memory.

Main Memory

Main memory is where programs and data are kept when the processor is actively using them. When programs and data become active, they are copied from secondary memory into main memory where the processor can interact with them. A copy remains in secondary memory. Main memory is intimately connected to the processor, so moving instructions from the program and data into and out of the processor is very fast. Main memory is sometimes called RAM. RAM stands for Random Access Memory. "Random" means that the memory cells can be accessed in any order.

When people say that a computer has "512 megabytes of RAM" they are talking about how big its main memory is. One megabyte of memory is enough to hold approximately one million characters of a word processing document. (There will be more about bytes and megabytes later on in these notes.) Nothing permanent is kept in main memory. Sometimes data are placed in main memory for just a few seconds, only as long as they are needed.

QUESTION 6:

Imagine that you are using a computer to write a letter.

  • Where is the is the word processor program that you are running located?
  • Where are the characters you have typed?
